title: 15 foods to boost the immune system
author: Lana Burgess
description: A strong immune system helps a person stay healthy by fighting off bacteria and viruses. In this article, we look at foods that can help to boost the immune system, including turmeric, ginger, garlic, kefir, green tea, and blueberries. We also cover the scientific reasons why these foods promote immune system health.
cleaned_text: A strong immune system helps to keep a person healthy. Berries, oily fish, turmeric, kefir, and other foods provide nutrients that support the immune system. The immune system consists of organs, cells, tissues, and proteins. Together, these carry out bodily processes that fight off pathogens, which are the viruses, bacteria, and foreign bodies that cause infection or disease. When the immune system comes into contact with a pathogen, it triggers an immune response. The immune system releases antibodies, which attach to antigens on the pathogens and kill them. Incorporating specific foods into the diet may strengthen a person's immune response. Read on to discover 15 foods that boost the immune system. A healthful, balanced diet plays a vital role in staying well. The following foods may help to boost the immune system: 1. Blueberries [Blueberries](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/287710.php) contain a type of flavonoid called anthocyanin, which has [antioxidant](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/301506.php) properties that can help boost a person's immune system. A [2016 study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4863266/) Researchers found that people who ate foods rich in flavonoids were less likely to get an upper respiratory tract infection, or common cold, than those who did not. 2. Dark chocolate Dark chocolate contains an [antioxidant called theobromine](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4335269/) Free radicals are molecules that the body produces when it breaks down food or comes into contact with pollutants. Free radicals can damage the body's cells and may contribute to disease. Despite its potential benefits, dark chocolate is high in [calories](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/245588.php) and saturated fat, so it is important to eat it in moderation. 3. Turmeric Turmeric is a yellow spice that many people use in cooking. It is also present in some alternative medicines. Consuming turmeric may improve a person's immune response. This is due to the qualities of [curcumin](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/318405), a compound in turmeric. According to a [2017 review](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5664031/) 4. Oily fish Salmon, tuna, pilchards, and other oily fish are a rich [source of omega-3 fatty acids](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3257669/) According to a [2014 report](https://ard.bmj.com/content/73/11/1949), long-term intake of [omega-3](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/40253.php) fatty acids may reduce the risk of [rheumatoid arthritis](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/info/rheumatoid-arthritis/) (RA). RA is a chronic autoimmune condition that occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks a healthy part of the body. 5. Broccoli Broccoli is another [source of vitamin C](https://academic.oup.com/biohorizons/article/doi/10.1093/biohorizons/hzs004/220345). It also contains potent antioxidants, such as sulforaphane. For these reasons, it is a good choice of vegetable to eat regularly to support immune system health. 6. Sweet potatoes Sweet potatoes are [rich in beta carotene](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3551189/) [Beta carotene](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/252758.php) is a source of [vitamin](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/195878.php) A. It helps to make skin healthy and may even provide some [protection against skin damage](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3583891/) 7. Spinach Spinach may boost the immune system, as it contains many essential nutrients and antioxidants, [including](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/316488658_NUTRITIONAL_VALUE_OF_SPINACIA_OLERAECEA_SPINACH-AN_OVERVIEW): - flavonoids - carotenoids - vitamin C - vitamin E Vitamins C and E can help [support the immune system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23830380) [Research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4863266/) 8. Ginger People use [ginger](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/265990.php) in a variety of dishes and desserts, as well as in teas. According to a review, ginger has anti-inflammatory and antioxidative properties and is likely to offer health benefits. However, more research is necessary to confirm whether or not it can effectively prevent illness. 9. Garlic Garlic is a common home remedy for the prevention of colds and other illness. One [review](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3928210/) The group of participants taking a [placebo](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/306437.php) had more than double the number of colds between them than those taking the garlic supplements. However, the researchers concluded that more research is necessary to determine whether or not garlic can help to prevent colds. 10. Green tea [Green tea](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/269538.php) contains only a small amount of caffeine, so people can enjoy it as an alternative to black tea or [coffee](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/270202.php). Drinking it may also strengthen the immune system. As with blueberries, green tea contains flavonoids, which [may reduce](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4863266/) 11. Kefir Kefir is a fermented drink that contains live cultures of bacteria that are beneficial for health. Initial research suggests that drinking kefir may boost the immune system. According to a [2017 review](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28222814) - fighting bacteria - reducing [inflammation](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/248423.php) - increasing antioxidant activity The majority of the research that supports this was carried out on animals or in a laboratory. Researchers need to perform additional studies to understand how kefir may prevent disease in humans. 12. Sunflower seeds Sunflower seeds can make a tasty addition to salads or breakfast bowls. They are a rich [source of vitamin E](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/275653985_THERAPEUTIC_POTENTIAL_OF_SUNFLOWER_SEEDS_AN_OVERVIEW), an antioxidant. In the same way as other antioxidants, [vitamin E improves immune function](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23830380) 13. Almonds Almonds are another excellent source of [vitamin E](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/jsfa.2659) [magnesium](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/286839.php), and fiber. A small handful or a quarter of a cup of almonds is a healthful snack that may benefit the immune system. 14. Oranges or kiwifruit (kiwis) Oranges and kiwis are an excellent source of vitamin C, which is the vitamin that many people turn to when they feel a cold developing. While scientists are still not sure exactly how it helps, vitamin C [may reduce](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23830380) 15. Red bell pepper For people trying to avoid the sugar in fruit, red bell peppers are an excellent alternative source of vitamin C. Stir-frying and roasting both preserve the nutrient content of red bell peppers better than steaming or boiling, according to a [study on cooking methods](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3866734/) The following lifestyle strategies may make a person's immune system stronger: - avoiding smoking - exercising regularly - maintaining a healthy weight - avoiding alcohol or drinking in moderation - getting enough sleep - minimizing [stress](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/145855.php) - practicing correct hand-washing and oral hygiene Enjoying the 15 immune-boosting foods covered in this article may strengthen people's immune system and improve their ability to fight off infections. That said, it is important to remember that the immune system is complex. Eating a healthful, balanced diet is just one way to support immune health. It is also essential to be mindful of the other lifestyle factors that may affect immune system health, such as exercising and not smoking. Anyone who gets frequent colds or other illnesses and is concerned about their immune system should speak to a doctor.
